perturbation.original_text: If the Investment Adviser is required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser shall make such payment within 30 days  after each month-end in the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense  Waiver, the Fund shall make such payment within 30 days after each month-end.
perturbation.changed_text: If the Investment Adviser is required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser shall make such payment within 60 days after each month-end in the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense Waiver, the Fund shall make such payment within 90 days after each month-end.
perturbation.explanation: The modification extends the payment deadlines for both the Investment Adviser and the Fund beyond a reasonable timeframe. While there isn't a strict federal law mandating a specific shorter payment period for such reimbursements *in this specific context*, extending it significantly (to 60 and 90 days) could be challenged under general fiduciary duty principles or state-specific investment regulations requiring timely settlements, introducing potential non-compliance issues, especially if delays harm the fund's performance. Industry standards would suggest quicker reimbursements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential breach of fiduciary duty; possible violation of state investment regulations requiring timely settlements

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall continue in effect for a period of one year from the date of its execution and from year to year thereafter provided such  continuance is specifically approved by a majority of the trustees of the Trust who (i) are not "interested persons" of the Trust or any other party  to this Agreement, as defined in the 1940 Act, and (ii) have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of this Agreement ("Non- Interested Trustees").
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall continue in effect for a period of five years from the date of its execution, with no requirement for annual renewal or approval by the trustees.
perturbation.explanation: This change eliminates the requirement for annual renewal by disinterested trustees, potentially violating Section 15(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940, which mandates that investment advisory contracts be approved annually by a majority of disinterested trustees. Removing this safeguard weakens investor protection and introduces non-compliance with federal regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 15(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940

perturbation.original_text: The Investment Adviser shall have the option to recover the full amount waived, paid or reimbursed (the Expense  Waiver) by the Investment Adviser on any day on which the Fund's Net Investment Income exceeds zero. In no event, however, shall  the Expense Waiver, or any portion thereof, constitute an obligation of the Fund to the Investment Adviser on any such day unless  the Investment Adviser has expressly exercised its right to recover all or a portion of the Expense Waiver on that day, in which case  such portion of the Expense Waiver elected by the Investment Adviser for recovery that day shall then be due and payable. If, and to  the extent, the payment by the Fund to the Investment Adviser of the Expense Waiver would cause the Fund's Net Investment Income  to fall below zero, such payment shall be deferred until such date on which the
perturbation.changed_text: The Investment Adviser shall have the right to recover the Expense Waiver at any time, and the Fund shall prioritize such reimbursement over all other operational expenses. The Fund must reimburse the Investment Advisor, irrespective of the Fund's current Net Investment Income.
perturbation.explanation: This modification compels the Fund to reimburse the Investment Advisor for the Expense Waiver without considering the Fund's financial health, thus possibly causing a negative Net Investment Income. This change potentially violates the fiduciary duty of the Trust's trustees to act in the best interests of the Fund and its shareholders and potentially violates SEC regulations requiring funds to maintain a positive net asset value.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Fiduciary Duty, potential SEC regulations regarding Net Asset Value
